Fundamentals like global growth and corporate profits have remained at decade highs over the last year, and have been cited by investors as reason to remain confident in the markets despite a dramatic correction in February and again in early April over interest rate hike apprehension and trade war fears.

"Our central case is that stocks move higher, because we think corporate profits really are the key driver of equity markets, and we see corporate profits looking pretty strong," Grace Peters, a global investment strategist at J.P. Morgan Private Bank, told CNBC's "Squawk Box Europe" Thursday.

"Technology is one of our key sectors that we're very positive on," Peters said, but specified that the bank has more recently moved preferences from solely internet and FAANG stocks (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google) toward other, more cyclical parts of the sector.

The strategist was also bullish on tech stocks, despite pressure on the sector following waves of scandal like Facebook's Cambridge Analytica controversy, fears of regulation and production and safety issues surrounding automation and vehicles.

"Of course there's always the risk that markets could end lower," Peters said, noting that if the strong economic picture does break down, investors will start questioning valuation, which has been at historically high levels.
A strategist at J.P. Morgan Private Bank sees positive news ahead for equity investors, despite growing fears in the investment community that major indexes may have topped out.
But she cited the recent market pullbacks as having made valuations look more reasonable in the context of the synchronized growth picture that remains strong.
Market turmoil in the first days of April saw its worst second-quarter open since the Great Depression, though the numbers have since rebounded.
This includes semiconductors and other areas that benefit from structural trends like the cloud and artificial intelligence.
The bank expects to get further evidence of this in the first-quarter reporting season that begins next week.
"I think regulation is likely to step up, but we still see a very solid structural story for tech."
Stocks have had a rocky few months after a historically high 2017.
